awd_titl_txt: Computational Prediction of Enantioselectivity in Metal-Catalyzed Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Many molecules are chiral, which means that they can exist in two forms that are mirror images, analogous to right and left hands. Very often the right and left hand forms interact differently with biological systems, sometimes with profound consequences. One hand may be beneficial while the other hand may also be beneficial, have no effect, or be harmful. As a result, the handedness property is an extremely important consideration in the design and manufacture of molecules such as pharmaceuticals. The most efficient syntheses of chiral molecules use catalysts that are also chiral.  Unfortunately, the synthesis of chiral catalysts often requires inefficient trial and error approaches. In this project, Professors Wiest and Helquist at the University of Notre Dame employ computational chemistry, machine learning, and organic chemistry to develop efficient, fast, and accurate methods to predict how to make chiral molecules. In collaboration with a major pharmaceutical company, these methods are improving access to molecules of importance to the pharmaceutical industry. This new approach to computationally-driven synthesis and the close, long-term collaboration with industry creates unique experiences for their students. These students participate in industrial internships and interdisciplinary training at AstraZeneca in Sweden.  The two senior researchers are actively engaging in broadening participation initiatives at the University of Notre Dame and in the Midwest. These activities include mentoring undergraduate students from underrepresented groups through the Building Bridges program and summer research for high school students.
 
With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Wiest and Dr. Helquist of the University of Notre Dame continue the development of the quantum guided molecular mechanics (Q2MM) method for the automated parameterization of transition state force fields (TSFFs) which are then used for the high-throughput virtual screening of enantioselective catalysts (CatVS).  A number of methodological improvements, such as machine learning, new interfaces, and automated parameterization procedures, and TSFFs for new reactions of interests for the synthetic organic community are developed. On the application side, the new methods are used for rapid prototyping of novel catalysts for hydrogen atom transfer reactions and for high throughput screening of virtual libraries for an enantioselective version of a novel cross-coupling reaction developed by the team. The Q2MM and CatVS code, as well as the validated force fields continue to be available to the scientific community free of charge via github.com/q2mm. The combined computational and experimental approach, combined with the close collaboration with AstraZeneca, provides a unique interdisciplinary training environment for the undergraduate and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research in the group led by Prof. P. Helquist and Prof. O. Wiest at the University of Notre Dame has resulted in the development of new technology for the computationally based design of catalysts for the efficient production of compounds having specific three-dimensional structures known as enantiomers. Such compounds are chiral and encompass a large percentage of the world’s largest selling pharmaceuticals as well as other classes of compounds having scientific, technical, and industrial applications. Chiral compounds can occur as either of two enantiomers. Having means to produce chiral compounds as individual enantiomers is of paramount importance for pharmaceuticals. The two enantiomers of drug molecules may have drastically different effects, whereby one may have desired therapeutic properties but the other may be toxic. An example is the anti-inflammatory drug naproxen, the active ingredient of Aleveä, which is used by about 50% of the US population. One enantiomer has beneficial effects but the other exhibits undesirable liver toxicity.

 

Traditionally, either of two approaches have been employed to obtain the individual enantiomers. One approach is to produce a mixture of two enantiomers by ordinary chemical processes followed by separating the two components. However, these separations are typically difficult, inefficient, and waste more than half of the material. Second is a trial-and-error approach in which various catalysts are tested to determine which ones provide high proportions of one enantiomer. It often requires screening of several hundred catalysts, which is costly in terms of materials and effort.

 

The intellectual merit of the project derives from the development of modern computational methods to address this challenge. In collaboration with Dr. Per-Ola Norrby (Sweden), we developed Q2MM/CatVS, combining the accuracy of quantum mechanical calculations to describe how molecules react with the speed and economy of molecular mechanics calculations. These methods can perform in silico screens of catalysts to accurately predict the percentage of either enantiomer of the products that will be obtained. This screening can even be done for completely newly designed catalysts that have not yet been prepared. Whereby traditional screening may require months in the laboratory, the computational screening can be conducted within hours on a commonly available computer. Therefore, in silico screening bypasses the cost and effort to obtain new catalysts that may or may not be effective. Only the catalysts for which the in silico screening predicts satisfactory performance would be synthesized.  

 

This approach has been applied to a diverse range of reactions, including alkene hydrogenations, ketone and imine reductions, allylic aminations, 1,4-addition reactions of unsaturated ketones, and alkene chain-walking arylations. The catalysts have employed many metals but especially palladium, nickel, rhodium, iridium, iron, and ruthenium. These computational methods have also been successful in “proofreading” prior published research of others to determine whether reported results on obtaining enantiomers was correct. The methods have identified errors in previous reports, and the earlier researchers have corrected their findings.

 One indication of the importance of any reaction is the extent to which it is employed in large-scale manufacturing of valuable products. An important aspect of the broader impact of the project, this work has been done in collaboration with one of the world’s largest pharmaceutical companies. Company scientists were asked to set priorities for enantioselective reactions that would be of greatest importance in the company’s manufacturing processes. These reactions became the primary focus of the development of the computational methods. Due to their success, the computational methods is now incorporated into the workflow of the company.

 Another broad impact is in biomedical research where we demonstrated the applicability of the computational methods in another field. In a separate project in collaboration with scientists at Purdue University who study the mechanisms of action of enzymes, the computational methods have been adapted to a fundamentally important enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of cholesterol in cells. Enzymes are catalysts that are large peptides rather than the types of metal catalysts that have been the prior subjects of the Q2MM protocol. The application of this method to the enzyme has provided atomic level resolution of the reactions that the enzyme catalyzes. A potential impact of such enzyme studies in general is that they may provide a means for development of drugs that may either enhance or inhibit the actions of enzymes in disease states.

 The broadest impacts of this research are new intellectual contributions to the scientific community and the training of the students and other investigators who have developed the computational methods under the mentorship of the PI and co-PI. These trainees have been well prepared for their professional careers and have now entered the scientific workforce in either academic or industrial sectors. The methods have been disseminated throughout the scientific community by publication of several papers in journals, by external presentations in many venues, and by distribution of the computational protocols on the Internet.
